Title: Need some way for variables to provide multiple arguments
description:
Using the external tools launcher, if I want to prompt for a variable using
${string_prompt}, I don't have a flexible way to supply multiple arguments to
the external tool.  E.g. setup the following file as an external tool, if I have
a single ${string_prompt}, and I type in "foo bar" to the prompt, argument two
never gets set.  Using multiple string_prompts is problematic as you may not
know how many extra arguments you need to supply (not having enough prompts, or
having to clear the prompt for args you don't want).  I understand that this
needs to be the way it is for things like file variables which may have spaces
in them, so there probably needs to be some way for a variable to "escape" from
the standard parsing and be able to provide multiple args to the external process.

Title: CVS support for ssh is very weak
description:
Sorry for the maybe somewhat rude tone, but there are several deficiencies which
make using CVS truly annoying under Eclipse:

1) No support for environment variables. Things like CVS_RSH are not recognized,
causing to always have to switch the setting from "pserver" to "ssh". Who uses
pserver anyway in these days?

2) No support for public key authentication. This is the worst deficiency, as it
requires storing the password in clear text somewhere (maybe somewhat obscured
in binary form, but at least de facto clear text as it needs to be used for the
log in process). This alone is a risk that one cannot take on a computer where
other people are working, and which prohibits the use of Eclipse in such a case!
It is not possible to use Eclipse CVS/ssh without entering a user name and
password. The password should be optional for correctly installed public keys!

3) No canonical CVS/Root string. The command line CVS client cannot be used with
that setup without overriding the Root with "-d".

4) No recognition of host or user keys in $HOME/.ssh.

As using CVS is a first step towards starting to use Eclipse, the terrible lack
of support for it makes its usefulness very limited. It should not be hard to
change this, at least for all Unix-like systems.

Title: [KeyBindings] Bind 'Esc' and it no longer works as a cancel action
description:
I20030910

Esc, e.g. Esc w for Clear Mark
2. Open a Java or Text editor
3. Press Ctrl+j to start incremental find
4. Press Esc
Observer: the incremental find mode is not left

1. Open a Java file
2. At a valid location press Ctrl + Space to open content assist
3. Press Esc
Observer: content assist is not closed

listener never receives the Esc.

Removing the key binding fixes the problem.

Title: [ActivityMgmt] Perspectives don't respect activity enablement
description:
When an activity disables a view's prefix, I would expect it to not be added to 
perspectives automatically anymore. For example, JDT Debug contributes a view 
(org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.DisplayView) to the Debug perspective provided by 
Debug UI. If I disable an activity that filters "org.eclipse.jdt.debug.*" and 
then create the Debug perspective, I would expect the perspective to be created 
without this view.

In addition, I think views contributed to perspectives (and not declared 
visible="false") should appear automatically when the associated activity is 
enabled. Whether or not they should automatically disappear is debatable.

It appears the the configurator does not call bundleContext.install for the 
new plugins and this is caused by the caching the timestamp of the 
configuration at the wrong time.

The timestamp processed last should be saved after the installBundles() method 
finishes.
